qas.question: What type of doctrines are contained in the Mimamsa  school?
How did the Mimamsa school view the soul?
What was the focus of the Mimamsa school of philosophy?
How did the Mimamsa school consider dharma?
What school disagreed with the principles of the Mimamsa school?
What type of doctrine does Mimamsa not have?
What school focuses on the existence of God?
Mimamsa rejected the epistemology and metaphysics of what?
What school agreed with the Mimamsa's understanding of Upanishads?
What did Mimamsakas consider as of equal importance as the rituals?

context: The metaphysics in <b6_0>Mīmāṃsā<b6_0/> school consists of <b5_0>both <a0_0>atheistic and theistic<b5_0/><a0_0/> doctrines and the school showed little interest in systematic examination of the existence of God. Rather, it held that the soul is <a1_0>eternal<a1_0/> omnipresent, inherently active spiritual essence, then focussed on the epistemology and metaphysics of <a2_0><b7_0>dharma<b7_0/><a2_0/>. To them, dharma meant <a3_0>rituals and duties<a3_0/>, not devas (gods), because devas existed only in name. The Mīmāṃsākas held that the Vedas are "eternal authorless infallible", that Vedic vidhi (injunctions) and mantras in rituals are prescriptive karya (actions), and the rituals are of primary importance and merit. They considered the <b9_0>Upanishads<b9_0/> and other self-knowledge, spirituality-related texts to be of secondary importance, a philosophical view that the <a4_0><b8_0>Vedanta<b8_0/> school<a4_0/> disagreed with.
